title: Thursday, 11th October 2018

bodyHTML:
11:07 am

Well, this is fun!

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Nately Ahoy ahoy
Manxish Morning Lemmings
Soundbuy Morning...............fun??

Let's start from the top. Everything's down.

More generally, though, it's because of the Fed. The Fed's crazy.

Tom Dalgleish 0.000000000000000000000000%

"I think the Fed is making a mistake. They're so tight. I think the Fed has gone crazy," Trump told reporters on the tarmac in Pennsylvania.

11:11 am

"I really disagree with what the Fed is doing," Trump said.

andyalan10 Ahoy ahoy from the Newhaven Dieppe ferry
Nately Crazy Fed, cutting taxes, raising spending, causing an inflationary boom.

Which moves us into interesting territory, right? I mean, inevitable territory, but I'm not sure we've had any leader in modern times going against the central bank so explicitly.

Bluesky21 Trump’s pitch is to blame the Fed for the market going down ... after taking personal credit for it going up

Mouselet Maybe I picked the wrong time for a six-month sabbatical
Excel Developer "Crazy"? We're not yet at POTUS slams Fed Chair against wall https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/13/business/economy/a-president-at-war-with-his-fed-chief-5-decades-before-trump.html "“Martin, my boys are dying in Vietnam, and you won’t print the money I need,” he said."
Bavaria blu Why does Trump think Fred is crazy?

Which adds another element of confusion to the possibility that we're at the end of the 2009 bull run.

Jarvis2009 Argentina and Turkey it is commonplace...

BE11:15am

One sign is the steep rise in the number of M&A deals worldwide. Earlier in the spring, the monthly value of M&A transactions closed in on USD600bn, suggesting that the sustained favorable financial environment has encouraged companies to actively invest in their businesses or acquire other firms. There were also spikes in M&A activity in 1999-2000 and 2006-07. In the current bull market, M&A activity increased in late 2015 and early 2017, but in those cases, companies and investors were buoyed by the benign financial environment.

Bluesky21 HL talked about market sentiment slowing client inflows
11:15 am
BE11:16am

There's also feeling happy. You all know what happens when you feel happy.

Mouselet Scottish Mortgage down substantially, which is odd since I thought it was a fairly conservative investment trust and shouldn't move that much more than the market
BE11:16am

Another sign is the increase in the number of bullish investors since the start of the year. The Investors Intelligence bull/bear index reached 66.7 in
mid-January, the highest bull reading since 1987. Not long after, investor
sentiment deteriorated sharply in the wake of the so-called VIX shock, but
the bull/bear index was back up to 61.8 on 5 October (Figure 2). Last year,
investors were concerned about Fed tightening and the Trump
administration's economic program, but investors are now mostly positive
about the outlook for the US economy and corporate earnings, backed by
strong economic data.

Bluesky21 @ Mouselet - sarcasm?
Bluesky21 Given their high tech exposure?
Mouselet No, error
hedgehog scotmortgage = amazon
Mouselet Thank you for rectifying my error
BE11:16am

That's all from Mitsubishi, which I include because it was the first "we're down" type thing I opened.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And here's the second. Barclays.

BE11:17am

In our view the two main catalysts behind the current equity selloff were recent commentary by Fed officials on terminal level of rates and by the Trump Administration on US-China trade. Fundamentals have not changed but we expect volatility to remain elevated in the short term and do not recommend buying this dip.

Jamie Powell (FT Alphaville) What??? Don't buy the dip??
BE11:18am

The Fed commentary was Williams and Powell suggesting a more optimistic view about the economy relative to market consensus

Excel Developer @Bryce : USA existing home sales and USA automobile sales have both peaked, showing Fed tightening (or is that removing accommodation) is having real impact on USA economy. I'm anxious about SP500 earnings season next week.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

And Powell saying “there’s really no reason to think that this cycle can’t continue for quite some time, effectively indefinitely” + “interest rates are still accommodative, but we’re gradually moving to a place where they’ll be neutral…We may go past neutral. But we’re a long way from neutral at this point, probably”.

BE11:18am

So:

Mouselet ... brief pause while I notice that I FORGOT TO SET A STOP-LOSS ON THE TECH TRACKER grr
BE11:19am

Economic and earnings growth has been exceptionally strong this year (especially during the second quarter) even after stripping out the one time effect of the Tax bill. However, our and consensus view is that this was a sugar high from fiscal spending and is likely to dissipate over the next few quarters. After a ~20% increase in earnings growth this year, consensus expectations are for 2019 S&P 500 earnings growth to moderate to below 10%. We expect to be even lower given the late stage of the business cycle. Against this backdrop, the Fed commentary has made equity investors worried that perhaps the Fed is likely to get ahead of the curve.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

So, everyone out of cyclicals and into what we euphemistically call defensives.

Excel Developer @BE: utilities do have a lower beta.

pancakes or waffles As noted by esteemed technician Katie Martin, the vomiting camel has reared its ugly head (or back?) on the S&P - the jig is up, guys

Where to start? How about Aston Martin?

Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings PLC (AML:LSE): Last: 1,519, down 91.2 (-5.66%), High: 1,620, Low: 1,509, Volume: 1.18m
Excel Developer more ayers rock than vomiting camel. @pancakes
BE11:22am

(Just noticed its code is AML! Heh.)

11:23 am
BE11:23am

We have our first sellside coverage. From Jefferies, which wasn't on the ticket so isn't locked to the one-month blackout.

TonaldDrump AML as in Leukaemia?
BE11:23am

And, uh, they're not keen.

BE11:23am

With an IPO that should have included some primary capital, the selling shareholders may have missed a chance to start a relationship with public equity markets on the right foot. Shares have since drifted to a level which better reflects execution risk but 1) still pitches AML at the very top of luxury stocks on 2020E using comparable accounting and 2) ignores FCF and liquidity risk. We initiate coverage at Underperform with a target price of 1,400p.

Mouselet Anti money laundering seems likely to be more on the minds of a certain subset of the Aston-purchasing fraternity?
11:24 am
BE11:24am

The most interesting bit in here, I'd suggest, is with reference to the balance sheet.

BE11:24am

Jefferies really isn't impressed that the exit involved no new cash raised.

GBKrona AML - Alphaville Markets Live
Mouselet joy, I have been charged 29p per day for a week because the bank takes more than a week to transfer cash from share-dealing account to current account
BE11:25am

We continue to think the AML IPO should have been a mix of primary and secondary, in order to address low liquidity. The conversion of Preference shares into equity addressed leverage and should take net debt to EBITDA below 2x on our numbers by year end. However, it brought no new liquidity. The June 30 balance sheet shows £71m of gross cash on the balance sheet, a rather small number for a company growing at a double-digit rate and negative net working capital of £235m, 20% of forecast 2018 revenue, of which £582 under Trade and other payables.

Soundbuy AML - just waiting for a recall on those faulty ejector seats.....
11:26 am
BE11:26am

From management comments

BE11:26am

we understand that broadly half of that position represents deposits from customers

BE11:26am

to secure deliveries of limited edition cars, mostly Zagatos and Valkyries. This suggests to us that [1] deposits are used to fund working capital instead of being ring-fenced and [2] AML should raise debt to create a liquidity buffer. In our valuation we reduce NWC by an estimated 250m value of customer deposits.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian And the circus and casino that we all base our lives on continues unquestioned......
11:27 am
BE11:27am

(Breaking up the quote boxes because they trigger ML's brilliantly efficient spam blocker, BTW.)

irish hedge fund guy any thought on Patisserie Valerie which was valued at £425m compared to £322m on similar Costa exit multiple. I looked at the main trading entity stonebeach and the cash balances really started moving in the last 3 years which was when they stopped paying dividends. If you good the birmingham address the main office building is interesting, on a residential street. Amazing still in this day and age that these things happen.
BE11:28am

Against that very narrow margin for error you have Aston Martin moving downwards into markets it knows very little about.

There's also a few pages in there about IFRS, which I'll work through later, the gist of which is that delivered numbers understate operating leverage

Nately @Irish - another Luke Johnson "success". Haven't read all the rumours but if cash nicked, CAKE can survive. Sounds more likely that accounts were fraudulent IMO, & the cash never existed & the profits were never made (in which case, zero). All IMO.
Flaneur Relax - a short, sharp multi-theatre war with the SCO is just what we need to get demand moving again... give it 6 months or so..
TonaldDrump brand valued at c.$3.6bn would expect that to have traction most places
BE11:30am

So ... why on earth are you paying more than Ferrari and Hermes for this thing?

BE11:30am

On the upside, a luxury OEM like AML can structurally deliver exceptional returns on invested capital (50+% post tax vs negative today and 15% expected in 2019E). However these are already built into multiples that set AML at the top of the luxury sector and above Ferrari and Hermes. On 2020E, AML is trading on 2.5x revenue and, using cash R&D metrics, on 33x earnings and 24x EBIT. Our 1,400p target price is DCF based with a modest discount applied for execution and liquidity risk. Ferrari currently trades at a 10% discount to our DCF fair value despite a lower risk profile.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Look forward to everyone driving an Aston and mistakenly thinking 'they have made it'.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Good note. I recommend it.

BE11:40am

We are cutting our 2018 PBT to £83m from £101m while for 2019 we move to £105m from £115m. This results in an 18% drop in EPS to 82p for 2018 with a 9% drop to 103.5p for 2019.

jaybond @wayneJ...completely agree...and what is more fun to add as spice is debt at such subsidiaries which none bother to look
Excel Developer James Murdoch as new chair of Tesla

wayneJ @jaybond - indeed. And ideally debt in non-consolidated subsidiaries with recourse to the parent.
BE11:41am

Performance & Valuation – The shares before today have performed relatively well with a rise of 2% vs a sector which is down c. 6% or so. On our revised forecasts the shares are now trading on a PE of 11.7x and an EV/EBITDA of 5.8x – broadly similar to long run averages. We continue to like the group’s leading market position and broad geographic spread but investor confidence will be dented following this announcement. We cut our TP to 1040p and move our recommendation back to Hold.

Flaneur @1st lt - True story this - just before the last crash I was nattering with a friend of the family who was a director of a very large Irish bank. I asked him what preparations they were making for the property crash and he looked at me in pity and said "theres a few more years to go yet".I thought he was fobbing me off but 18 months later his own son lost his house.Thats what shocked me the most - a Director of a bank in Ireland and he hadnt a notion what was about to happen.... so what hope do the proles have?
